title: Where did Russia come from? - Alex Gendler

options.text: The dense woodlands of Western Europe

options.label: B
options.text: The dense woodlands of Eastern Europe

options.label: C
options.text: The dense woodlands of Northern Europe

options.label: D
options.text: The dense woodlands of Southern Europe

options.label: B
options.text: Prince Rurik

options.label: C
options.text: Prince Vladimir I

options.label: D
options.text: Prince Nestor

options.label: B
options.text: The Kievan Rus History

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: Judaism

title: The race to sequence the human genome - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What was the main goal of the Human Genome Project?

options.label: A
options.text: To identify the genetic causes of specific diseases

options.label: B
options.text: To sequence the entire human genome over 15 years

options.label: C
options.text: To develop new medical treatments based on genetic research

options.label: D
options.text: To study the genetic differences between humans and other species

multiple-choice.question: What was the main difference between the Human Genome Project's approach and Celera's approach to sequencing the human genome?

options.label: A
options.text: The Human Genome Project used a more expensive technology, while Celera used a cheaper one

options.label: B
options.text: The Human Genome Project divided the genome into smaller chunks, while Celera chopped it up into a giant heap of small bits

options.label: C
options.text: The Human Genome Project focused on sequencing specific genes, while Celera focused on sequencing the entire genome

options.label: D
options.text: The Human Genome Project worked alone, while Celera collaborated with other researchers

multiple-choice.question: What was the Human Genome Project's second major principle?

options.label: A
options.text: That all of the project's data would be kept secret until publication

options.label: B
options.text: That all of the project's data would be shared publicly within 24 hours of collection

options.label: C
options.text: That the project would focus on sequencing specific genes related to disease

options.label: D
options.text: That the project would prioritize the sequencing of genes related to human development

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the Human Genome Project's approach to sequencing the genome?

options.label: A
options.text: The project was completed in just three years and at a fraction of the cost

options.label: B
options.text: The project was completed in just three years but at a significant cost

options.label: C
options.text: The project was completed in 15 years, but with a high degree of accuracy

options.label: D
options.text: The project was completed in 15 years, but with a significant risk of misassembly

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the challenges facing researchers in understanding the human genome?

options.label: A
options.text: Identifying the genetic causes of specific diseases

options.label: B
options.text: Developing new medical treatments based on genetic research

options.label: C
options.text: Understanding what most of our genes do and how they are controlled

options.label: D
options.text: Studying the genetic differences between humans and other species

options.label: B
options.text: Tiny water droplets

options.label: C
options.text: Air particles

options.label: D
options.text: Ice crystals

options.label: B
options.text: Sea fog

options.label: C
options.text: Brown fog

options.label: D
options.text: Carl (specific to San Francisco)

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sonic boom

options.label: C
options.text: To warn other vessels of their presence

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: 400 ft

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: To provide a visual reference for pilots

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: How can countries measure the well-being of their citizens?

multiple-choice.question: What does the Sustainable Economic Development Assessment (SATA) measure, in addition to a country's economic performance?

options.label: A
options.text: Only its social sustainability

options.label: B
options.text: Only its environmental sustainability

options.label: C
options.text: Both its social and environmental sustainability

options.label: D
options.text: Neither its social nor environmental sustainability

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main limitation of GDP as a measure of national growth?

options.label: A
options.text: It only measures economic growth, not social or environmental sustainability

options.label: B
options.text: It only measures economic growth, but does not account for inflation

options.label: C
options.text: It only measures economic growth, but does not account for changes in population

options.label: D
options.text: It only measures economic growth, but does not account for the well-being of citizens

multiple-choice.question: Which country is mentioned as having made significant strides in sustainability and governance through policies like funding for renewable resources and establishing a Central anti-corruption Bureau?

options.label: A
options.text: Morocco

options.label: B
options.text: Brazil

options.label: C
options.text: Poland

options.label: D
options.text: Korea

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the key factors that correlates highly with overall progress, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Economic growth

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental sustainability

options.label: C
options.text: Gender equality

options.label: D
options.text: Poverty reduction

multiple-choice.question: What is the main lesson from the examples of Poland, Morocco, and Brazil, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Improving well-being requires a lot of money

options.label: B
options.text: Improving well-being requires good leadership, clear goals, and policies focused on making the country and the world a better place

options.label: C
options.text: Improving well-being requires a strong military

options.label: D
options.text: Improving well-being requires a high level of education

title: 3 tips to boost your confidence - TED-Ed

multiple-choice.question: What is confidence, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to succeed without effort.

options.label: B
options.text: The feeling of being valuable, worthwhile, and capable.

options.label: C
options.text: The act of taking risks without fear.

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to predict the outcome of a challenge.

multiple-choice.question: What are the three factors that impact confidence, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Genes, environment, and choices.

options.label: B
options.text: Genes, social pressures, and personal choices.

options.label: C
options.text: Genes, choices, and brain chemistry.

options.label: D
options.text: Environment, brain chemistry, and personal choices.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a fixed mindset and a growth mindset, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A fixed mindset thinks abilities can be developed, while a growth mindset thinks they are fixed.

options.label: B
options.text: A fixed mindset thinks abilities are fixed, while a growth mindset thinks they can be developed.

options.label: C
options.text: A fixed mindset thinks abilities are developed through practice, while a growth mindset thinks they are innate.

options.label: D
options.text: A fixed mindset thinks abilities are innate, while a growth mindset thinks they are developed through practice.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of having a growth mindset, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to more failures and setbacks.

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to a decrease in self-esteem.

options.label: C
options.text: It leads to a decrease in motivation.

options.label: D
options.text: It leads to greater success and better grades.

multiple-choice.question: What is one practical tip for cultivating confidence, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Practice failure and give up easily.

options.label: B
options.text: Believe in your ability to improve and develop your talents.

options.label: C
options.text: Avoid taking risks and stay in your comfort zone.

options.label: D
options.text: Focus on your weaknesses and try to change them.

title: Where the Sidewalk Ends (LEGO Sculpture)

multiple-choice.question: What is the setting described in the first stanza of "Where the Sidewalk Ends"?

options.label: A
options.text: A busy city street

options.label: B
options.text: A peaceful, natural area

options.label: C
options.text: A place of darkness and despair

options.label: D
options.text: A location of great excitement and adventure

options.label: A
options.text: Stay in the city and continue to walk on the sidewalk

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Take a different route through the city

options.label: D
options.text: Stop walking altogether

options.label: A
options.text: A symbol of danger and warning

options.label: B
options.text: A guide for the speaker and the children to follow

options.label: C
options.text: A representation of the children's imagination

options.label: D
options.text: A sign of the speaker's confusion and uncertainty

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the "children" in the poem?

options.label: A
options.text: They are the main characters and the focus of the poem

options.label: B
options.text: They are a symbol of innocence and wonder

options.label: C
options.text: They are a distraction from the main theme of the poem

options.label: D
options.text: They are not relevant to the poem at all

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall tone of the poem?

options.label: A
options.text: Dark and melancholic

options.label: B
options.text: Peaceful and contemplative

options.label: C
options.text: Exciting and adventurous

options.label: D
options.text: Confusing and uncertain

title: ¿Qué causa la resistencia a los antibióticos? - Kevin Wu

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of self-talk?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate emotions

options.label: B
options.text: To motivate oneself

options.label: C
options.text: To plan and organize tasks

options.label: D
options.text: To perceive time

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the psychological treatment that focuses on regulating the tone of self-talk?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT)

options.label: B
options.text: Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR)

options.label: C
options.text: Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT)

options.label: D
options.text: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT)

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for self-talk that is spoken as if in conversation with another person?

options.label: A
options.text: Distanced self-talk

options.label: B
options.text: Instructional self-talk

options.label: C
options.text: Motivational self-talk

options.label: D
options.text: Negative self-talk

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential consequence of high levels of negative self-talk?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased self-esteem

options.label: B
options.text: Improved mood

options.label: C
options.text: Anxiety in children and adults

options.label: D
options.text: Better sleep quality

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of using self-talk to regulate emotions?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase stress levels

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease focus and concentration

options.label: C
options.text: To help regulate emotions and reduce stress

options.label: D
options.text: To improve cognitive function

title: Why do rivers curve?

multiple-choice.question: Compared to mountain streams, what is characteristic of the meandering rivers of the plains?

options.label: A
options.text: They are faster and more turbulent

options.label: B
options.text: They are slower and more winding

options.label: C
options.text: They are wider and deeper

options.label: D
options.text: They are narrower and shallower

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of a muskrat burrowing a den in one bank of a stream?

options.label: A
options.text: It strengthens the bank and makes the stream straighter

options.label: B
options.text: It weakens the bank and causes the stream to meander

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the stream's course

options.label: D
options.text: It causes the stream to change direction suddenly

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the width of a meandering stream and the length of one S-shaped meander?

options.label: A
options.text: The length is twice the width

options.label: B
options.text: The length is three times the width

options.label: C
options.text: The length is about six times the width

options.label: D
options.text: The length is inversely proportional to the width

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a river's meanders continue to grow curvier and curvier until they loop around and bumble into themselves?

options.label: A
options.text: The river becomes faster and more turbulent

options.label: B
options.text: The river follows a straighter path downhill and leaves behind an oxbow lake

options.label: C
options.text: The river changes direction suddenly

options.label: D
options.text: The river stops flowing altogether

multiple-choice.question: What is a crescent-shaped remnant that forms when a river follows a straighter path downhill and leaves behind a curved section of its former channel?

options.label: A
options.text: An oxbow lake

options.label: B
options.text: A billabong

options.label: C
options.text: A lago en herradura

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

title: Neil deGrasse Tyson on Surviving in Space without a Spacesuit

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why pigeons are able to find their way home from places they've never been?

options.label: A
options.text: They use visual maps.

options.label: B
options.text: They use Earth's magnetic field.

options.label: C
options.text: They use the angle of the sun.

options.label: D
options.text: They use a combination of visual maps, Earth's magnetic field, the angle of the sun, and smells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the brain in pigeons?

options.label: A
options.text: To process visual information.

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate body temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: To control flight patterns.

options.label: D
options.text: It is mostly made up of eyeballs.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of pigeons' "super eyes"?

options.label: A
options.text: They allow pigeons to see in complete darkness.

options.label: B
options.text: They allow pigeons to magnify their focus on objects.

options.label: C
options.text: They allow pigeons to see things that humans can't.

options.label: D
options.text: They allow pigeons to see colors that humans can't.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of self-talk in humans?

options.label: A
options.text: To communicate with others.

options.label: B
options.text: To process visual information.

options.label: C
options.text: To regulate body temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: To plan, work through difficult situations, and motivate oneself.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for self-talk that is done as if in conversation with another person?

options.label: A
options.text: Distanced self-talk.

options.label: B
options.text: Vocal self-talk.

options.label: C
options.text: Silent self-talk.

options.label: D
options.text: Negative self-talk.

title: ¿Qué le da el valor a un billete de dólar? - Doug Levinson

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean to be a Native American?

options.label: A
options.text: That you were among the largest group of people living in the United States of America.

options.label: B
options.text: That you are among the most important groups of people living in the United States of America.

options.label: C
options.text: That you were one of the original people who lived in the United States of America.

options.label: D
options.text: That you were one of the founding fathers of the United States of America.

multiple-choice.question: There are more than 500 Native American tribes and nations. Which 5 tribes were the largest?

options.label: A
options.text: Apache, Cherokee, Iroquois, Navajo, and Sioux

options.label: B
options.text: Cherokee, Anasazi, Chippewa, Pawnee, and Osage

options.label: C
options.text: Apache, Iroquois, Chippewa, Pawnee, and Lakota

options.label: D
options.text: Navajo, Sioux, Lakota, Pawnee, and Osage

multiple-choice.question: What does the tribe name Cherokee mean?

options.label: A
options.text: People known as farmers.

options.label: B
options.text: People known as warriors.

options.label: C
options.text: People with another language.

options.label: D
options.text: People with another religion.

multiple-choice.question: What is a "wigwam"?

options.label: A
options.text: A farming technique that increases crops.

options.label: B
options.text: A shelter built from branches, leaves, and grass.

options.label: C
options.text: A shelter built from mud bricks and clay.

options.label: D
options.text: A fishing technique that used a spear.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Navajo tribe?

options.label: A
options.text: They were known for their skills in agriculture.

options.label: B
options.text: They were known for their skills in hunting.

options.label: C
options.text: They were known for their skills in fishing.

options.label: D
options.text: They were known for their skills in warfare.

multiple-choice.question: Their eyeballs are a major component of their skulls. On the video, they gave a comparison if humans had pigeon-like eyeballs. How big would the human eyeballs be?

options.label: A
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of tomatoes.

options.label: B
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of watermelons.

options.label: C
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of grapefruits.

options.label: D
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of baseballs.

multiple-choice.question: Why was Charles Darwin, the father of evolution theory, so interested in pigeons to support his theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Darwin knew that every country had a form of pigeons.

options.label: B
options.text: Darwin knew that despite the differences, pigeons all came from the Rock Dove.

options.label: C
options.text: Darwin was able to examine pigeons more easily than other animals.

options.label: D
options.text: Darwin thought the fancy pigeons would attract more attention than armadillos.

multiple-choice.question: What is the size of a pigeon's brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The size of your thumb

options.label: B
options.text: The size of a fingertip

options.label: C
options.text: The size of a walnut

options.label: D
options.text: The size of a golf ball

multiple-choice.question: What do pigeons' "super eyes" allow them to do?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to be more balanced and agile than humans.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows them to magnify their focus on objects.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows them to remember things humans can't.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows them to see things humans can't.

multiple-choice.question: Why did B.F. Skinner try and train pigeons during World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: He trained them to help crash enemy planes.

options.label: B
options.text: He trained them to deliver messages.

options.label: C
options.text: He trained them in order to make them aerial bombers.

options.label: D
options.text: He trained them to crack enemy messages.

What is one thing going to mosques more frequently linked to?

options.label: A
options.text: More tolerant views of people of other faiths

options.label: B
options.text: Greater civic engagement

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: None of the above

options.label: A
options.text: The white race

options.label: B
options.text: Christianity

options.label: C
options.text: White supremacy

options.label: D
options.text: Violence

options.label: A
options.text: Vocal

options.label: B
options.text: Silent

options.label: C
options.text: Negative

options.label: A
options.text: Planning

options.text: Motivation

options.label: C
options.text: Emotional regulation

options.label: D

title: Growth Mindset vs Fixed Mindset: An Introduction

multiple-choice.question: What do people with a growth mindset believe about intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a fixed trait that you're born with.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be developed through effort and challenge.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a combination of both fixed and developed traits.

options.label: D
options.text: It's only developed through genetics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of students with a fixed mindset in school?

options.label: A
options.text: To learn new things and develop their intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: To show how smart they are or hide how unintelligent they are.

options.label: C
options.text: To make friends and have fun.

options.label: D
options.text: To get good grades without putting in effort.

multiple-choice.question: How do students with a growth mindset view effort?

options.label: A
options.text: Negatively, as a sign of being unintelligent.

options.label: B
options.text: Positively, as a way to learn and develop their intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: Indifferently, as neither good nor bad.

options.label: D
options.text: As a way to impress others.

multiple-choice.question: What do students with a fixed mindset do when faced with a challenge or setback?

options.label: A
options.text: They try harder and see it as an opportunity to learn.

options.label: B
options.text: They give up because they think their setback means they're not smart.

options.label: C
options.text: They ask for help and try to find a solution.

options.label: D
options.text: They ignore the challenge and move on.

multiple-choice.question: Why do students with a growth mindset tend to do better in school?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they're naturally more intelligent.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have a fixed mindset and are more motivated.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they try harder in school, especially in the face of a challenge.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have more friends and social connections.

title: What happens when your DNA is damaged? - Monica Menesini

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Base excision repair enzyme

options.label: D
options.text: Nucleotide excision repair enzyme

options.label: C
options.text: Nucleotide excision repair

options.label: D
options.text: Non-homologous end joining

options.label: C
options.text: Homologous recombination

options.label: D
options.text: Non-homologous end joining

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Base excision repair and non-homologous end joining

title: How misused modifiers can hurt your writing

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the grammatical mistake that can dramatically change the meaning of a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: Misplaced modifier

options.label: B
options.text: Dangling modifier

options.label: C
options.text: Squinting modifier

options.label: D
options.text: Ambiguity

multiple-choice.question: Why do modifiers sometimes create unintentional ambiguity in a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are not linked clearly enough to the words they are referring to.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are too long.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are too short.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not necessary.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a dangling modifier?

options.label: A
options.text: "Having robbed the bank in record time, it was possible to make off with the town's chocolate rabbit as well."

options.label: B
options.text: "Town with world's largest chocolate bunny robbed by thief."

options.label: C
options.text: "Robbers who steal chocolate bunnies rapidly attract the outrage of onlookers."

options.label: D
options.text: "Chocolate bunny-thieving robbers rapidly attract the outrage of onlookers."

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the type of modifier that is stuck between two things and could feasibly refer to either?

options.label: A
options.text: Squinting modifier

options.label: B
options.text: Misplaced modifier

options.label: C
options.text: Dangling modifier

options.label: D
options.text: Ambiguity

multiple-choice.question: How can a modifier be clarified if it is a squinting modifier?

options.label: A
options.text: By putting it closer to its intended phrase.

options.label: B
options.text: By rewording the sentence so that the modifier no longer squints.

options.label: C
options.text: By removing the modifier altogether.

options.label: D
options.text: By changing the meaning of the sentence.
